about: An urban designer-planner, researcher, and architect by profession, Aeshna Prasad is deeply passionate and committed to addressing questions of urban resilience, sustainable development, and social equity – primarily through the lenses of affordable housing, infrastructure, critical conservation, and climate adaptation. She is currently in the final semester of her dual-degree program at Harvard GSD in the Master of Architecture in Urban Design and Master of Design Studies, Ecologies domain. Her keen interest in public space, incremental-affordable housing, and infrastructures of resilience has led her to continuously approach design as a tool for negotiation, experimentation & transformation. She is extremely interested in tackling contemporary urban challenges brought on by rapid urbanization, economic and political transitions, which lead to contested landscapes.Academically and professionally, Aeshna continues to engage with these subjects through her work as a teaching & research associate with professors like Rahul Mehrotra, David Gamble, Antione Picon, and Abby Spinak; courtesy numerous grants and awards she has received from institutions such as the Joint Center of Housing Studies and the Lakshmi Mittal South Asia Institute at Harvard; and via her work at the Harvard Innovation Lab where she incubated her social-impact venture ‘Sahayak' - an integrated mapping platform aimed at tackling mass-migration. Aeshna has also pursued numerous internships, most recently at Robert A.M Stern Architects, and full-time work with reputed Indian design studios before her master’s studies.In addition to urban planning and design, she is deeply interested in international development, policy, and advocacy. In line with this, her work has been spread across diverse geographies such as Mumbai, Cape Town, New York, Boston, and Colombia. She has also taken classes in Strategy, Leadership, Advanced Negotiation and Conflict Resolution. This she believes will help her manage, finance, and implement projects moving forward. Apart from her professional and academic pursuits, Aeshna has broadened her outlook and perspectives through various leadership positions and extra-curricular activities. She has served as Harvard Graduate Council Chair and Diversity and Inclusion Chair in the Student Forum, as co-chair of South Asia GSD, and as the editor of the Urban Design Department’s publication platform UD:ID. Armed with a multi-disciplinary skillset and multi-scalar design sensibilities, Aeshna is now looking for full-time job opportunities in urban design & planning.

JustMoney approaches money as a legal project. Created to meet demands both public and private, money depends on law for its definition, issue, and operation. That legal structure of money – its design – matters deeply. The website's aim is to encourage discussion, debate, and scholarship on money’s design and its reform towards a world that is as just as it is (economically) productive.

Despite the centrality of money’s design, it is marginalized as a public and academic concern. Most leave it to economists to explain. Economists do so according to disciplinary terms. Those terms set aside issues of money’s legal definition, creation, and change over time.  Banking and financial regulation scholars target the architecture of the current system, but an enormous territory remains outside those fields. JustMoney's contributors are interested in questions such as how:

• Societies configure governance as they build a sovereign unit of account
• Strategies to delegate credit creation to private financial institutions implicate democratic legitimacy
• The phenomena of instability and inequality relate to decisions about monetary design
• Public support in the figure of the payments system can perform both political and technical values

Those issues engage fields like constitutional law, civil rights, poverty law, and legal theory just as directly as fields defined as monetary or financial.  More generally, the issues the website hopes to raise cross disciplinary bounds to history, sociology, political science, anthropology, and the humanities, as well as economics.

Custom path of study combines economics, comparative law/legal history (via cross-enrollment at Harvard Law School), and other social sciences (sociology, government, history, etc.) and history of thought to build an integrated study of political economy studying both the activities of economic agents and the institution- and belief-structures that organize those activities. 

Used above, "institutions" includes not just macro-level governance (regulators, central banks, IMF, unions) and policy regimes (fiscal policy; antitrust, competition, labor, price regulation; etc.), but also the designs of basic "background" arrangements setting terms of economic interaction: contracts, property, money, corporate forms, etc. (This is distinct from "law and economics" and "institutional/political economics," which use economics to analyze law/institutions, because it begins from institutional indeterminacy, analyzes institutions via law and design thinking, and tracks consequences via economics.)

Studying political economy of contemporary China. Planned thesis explores financing in China’s emerging knowledge economy, focusing on legal-institutional factors structuring the growth of its indigenous startup and venture capital industries. 

Thesis will compare and contrast details of the Chinese and American institutional solutions to the "simultaneity problems" of fostering a venture capital sector and chart how different designs that address the same institutionally indeterminate functions yield different market dynamics, focusing on structural impacts on a) the direction of innovation, b) channels of access to vanguardist sectors, c) the pace and effectiveness of disruptive innovation regulatory response, and, relatedly, d) market and extra-market mechanisms of firm competition pressure. 

Thesis is part of a larger argument about the nature of China's and all market economies: "capitalist," "socialist," "mixed economy"? Or does a deeper indeterminacy belie those categories?
